seo.suggestedTitle: Claude Code Sub-agents: Build Multi-Agent Systems That Scale

gaps: No complete end-to-end project showing real-world multi-agent orchestration
Missing debugging and troubleshooting techniques for when agents fail
No coverage of cost optimization strategies across agent tiers (Opus/Sonnet/Haiku)
Limited examples of agent-to-agent communication patterns
No benchmarks or performance comparisons between single-agent vs multi-agent approaches
Missing coverage of how to handle agent failures and implement fallback strategies
strengths: Official docs have clear YAML frontmatter structure
Good explanation of built-in agents (Explore, Plan, general-purpose)
Shipyard provides good quickstart with basic examples
VoltAgent GitHub repo offers 100+ pre-built subagent templates

keyPoints: Subagents are Markdown files with YAML frontmatter
Each subagent runs in its own context window with custom system prompt
Subagents cannot spawn their own subagents (prevents infinite nesting)
Multi-agent with Opus 4 lead + Sonnet 4 subagents outperformed single Opus by 90.2%
Agents typically use 4x more tokens than chat, multi-agent 15x more
Token usage explains 80% of performance variance

expertInsights: Adam Wolf (Claude Code team): Sub agents work best when just looking for information and provide small summary back
Custom subagents can be brittle - consider using CLAUDE.md context with built-in Task/Explore
Making subagents argumentative and opinionated protects from bad design decisions
Max out at about 3-4 subagents total for most use cases
codeExamples: webdevtodayjason/sub-agents - CLI tool for managing subagents
commonProblems: Using subagents for implementation instead of information gathering
Allowing all tools to every agent (token waste, context pollution)
CLI version mismatch causing agent loading issues
YAML frontmatter syntax errors silently ignored
Claude inferring subagent function from name, overriding instructions
No mechanism to prevent parallel edits to same files
User preferences lost after context compacting (80K+ tokens wasted)

statistics.performanceGain: 90.2% improvement with multi-agent vs single agent (Anthropic internal eval)
statistics.tokenUsage: Multi-agent systems use ~15x more tokens than chat
statistics.costReduction: 70% cost reduction possible with intelligent Haiku/Sonnet/Opus allocation
statistics.contextPreservation: Each subagent gets fresh 200k context window

modelSelection.haiku: Code review, documentation, linting, high-volume tasks - fastest, cheapest
modelSelection.sonnet: Multi-file changes, debugging, architecture decisions - balanced (recommended)
modelSelection.opus: Large-scale refactoring, multi-agent orchestration, novel problem-solving - highest quality
